ai-mn83:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Mithilā in a Mithilā’s mango grove.
ai-mn83:2.1_0: Then the Buddha smiled at a certain spot.
ai-mn83:2.3_0: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
ai-mn83:2.4_0: Isn’t smiling with the Realized Ones.”
ai-mn83:2.5_0: So Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-mn83:2.6_0: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
ai-mn83:2.7_0: Isn’t smiling with the Realized Ones.”
ai-mn83:3.1_0: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, right here in Mithilā there was a just and principled king named Makhādeva, a great king who stood by his duty.
ai-mn83:3.2_0: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
ai-mn83:3.3_0: And he observed the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
ai-mn83:4.1_0: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Makhādeva’s son addressed his barber,
ai-mn83:4.2_0: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
ai-mn83:4.4_0: When many thousands of years had passed, the barber saw grey hairs growing on the king’s head.
ai-mn83:4.6_0: ‘The messengers of the gods have shown themselves to you. Grey hairs can be seen growing on your head.’
ai-mn83:4.7_0: ‘Well then, my dear barber, carefully pull them out with tweezers and place them in my cupped hands.’
ai-mn83:4.8_0: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the barber. They lifted the king’s trunk on the ground.
ai-mn83:4.9_0: The king gave the barber a prize village, then summoned the crown prince and said,
ai-mn83:4.10_0: ‘Dear prince, the messengers of the gods have shown themselves to me.
ai-mn83:4.11_0: Grey hairs can be seen growing on my head.
ai-mn83:4.13_0: Now it is time to seek heavenly pleasures.
ai-mn83:4.14_0: Come, dear prince, rule the realm.
ai-mn83:4.15_0: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-mn83:4.16_0: For dear prince, you too will one day see grey hairs growing on your head. When this happens, after giving a prize village to the barber and carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, you should shave off your hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-mn83:4.17_0: Kep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.
ai-mn83:4.18_0: Whatever generation is current when such good practice is broken, he is their final man.
ai-mn83:4.20_0: “Kep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.”’

ai-mn83:12.1_0: Nimi was the last of those kings, a just and principled king, a great king who stood by his duty.

ai-mn83:13.1_0: Once upon a time, Ānanda, while the gods of the Thirty-Three were sitting together in the Hall of Justice, this discussion came up among them:
ai-mn83:13.2_0: ‘The people of Videha are so fortunate, so very fortunate

ai-mn83:13.4_0: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
ai-mn83:13.5_0: And he observes the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.’
ai-mn83:13.6_0: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three,
ai-mn83:13.7_0: ‘Good sirs, would you like to see King Nimi?’
ai-mn83:13.8_0: ‘Good sir, I wish to see the king.’
ai-mn83:13.9_0: Now at that time it was the fifteenth day sabbath, and King Nimi had bathed his head and was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
